SENT.plain: A 48 years-old Japanese man suffered from marked xanthomas on ankles, knees, hand fingers, and foot joints due to insufficient control of serum hypercholesterolemia despite low density lipoprotein (LDL-C) absorptive therapy followed by treatment with potent anti-hypercholesterolemic agents
He had undergone surgical resection of xanthoma on the knee, foot and hand finger joints
Treatment with simvastatin returned the serum total cholesterol levels to nearly normal levels, followed by marked fluctuations
He subsequently experienced transient right-visual disturbance, and roentogenographic examination was performed
The patient was diagnosed as right-common carotid artery thrombosis
After the thrombotectomy of the right-common carotid artery, his visual power was markedly improved
